stream_context.summary: Kaze worked primarily on the 'craft' themed level. The main activities included brainstorming ideas for the level's five 'Yoshi Coins,' nerfing the powerful spin jump mechanic, and going through a detailed, iterative process of modeling and texturing a new 'Thimble Shy Guy' enemy from scratch. He also discussed his custom lighting/reflection shader and responded to community feedback on the level's blocky aesthetic.

development_findings.summary: The spin jump was nerfed because it was too powerful, allowing players to easily climb vertical surfaces and undermining the intended platforming challenges.
development_findings.quote: I think the spin jump is cool, but it's way too strong... It's a little impressive on the rest of the game's design.

development_findings.summary: The spin jump was redesigned to be a slow, aerial stall for recovering from mistakes, rather than a primary tool for gaining height or distance.
development_findings.quote: I want this to be a very slow thing, that you kind of like do not want to use, but that gives you a feeling of security when it's available to you.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a custom lighting effect to simulate reflectivity on surfaces, similar to a normal or specular map, without knowing the standard industry term for it, highlighting his practical, self-taught approach.
development_findings.quote: I don't know the name of it, but I know how to program it.

development_findings.summary: The team decided to add Shy Guys to the craft level to better align with the 'Return to Yoshi's Island' theme.
development_findings.quote: This is Yoshi's Island. We need Shy Guys.

development_findings.summary: Kaze defends the craft level's 'blocky' aesthetic against criticism, explaining it's an intentional choice to make the world feel like it's constructed from simple cardboard boxes.
development_findings.quote: I think it has to look blocky for the effect to work... Right now it's also just like cardboard boxes that I cut out. And I like that.

development_findings.summary: The team is brainstorming ideas for the level's five 'Yoshi Coins,' which are special objectives. Ideas include a secret cardboard flap entrance, a Peach rescue mission, and a Pink Bob-omb that opens a cannon.
Kaze replaced his original cotton ball cloud models after realizing players couldn't identify them and thought they were bombs, opting for a clearer design from a community member.
development_findings.quote: I didn't even know those bombs are clouds. Exactly my point. That's the issue.

development_findings.summary: The custom engine includes many quality-of-life improvements over the original SM64, such as being able to jump after a long jump and more consistent wall kick speeds, designed to be unnoticed by casual players.

context_findings.summary: Kaze enforces a strict creative constraint to only use characters, mechanics, and concepts from the N64 era or of the team's own invention to maintain a period-appropriate feel.
context_findings.quote: We're also not adding anything that was invented after Nintendo 64 unless we invented it ourselves, basically.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy prioritizes the core player experience over catering to niche speedrunning or glitch-hunting communities.
context_findings.quote: I'm not making changes specifically just so you can back amuse. If you can back amuse, that's great. I enjoyed it as well, but I'm not going to cater to that.

context_findings.summary: He has a strong opinion against certain mission types, like item-carrying quests, believing they are fundamentally not enjoyable.
context_findings.quote: Item carrying is just not fun. That's the issue.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is amused by the fact that he seems to have acquired his 'first real hater,' someone who dislikes every new video he uploads almost immediately.
While the game will be free due to its nature as a ROM hack, Kaze has considered a potential monetization model involving optional cosmetic purchases.
context_findings.quote: If I was allowed to, maybe I would. Actually, what would I do if I was allowed to charge for this game? Probably release the base game for free and then you could buy a skin or something.

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for ensuring the game's art aligns with the N64-era aesthetic, having previously replaced placeholder images of newer enemies with appropriate ones at Kaze's direction.
biobak.quote: I'm pretty sure we swapped those out. Because I know exactly what you're talking about and I know I don't want that. And I'm pretty sure Biobak swapped those out.

biobak.summary: Biobak is currently working on a 'dummy' model, which Kaze mentions is almost complete.

badub.summary: Kaze is waiting for Badub's music for the craft level and hopes for a dynamic score that adapts to the player's location within the level's different zones.
badub.quote: I'm gonna see what music Badub is gonna come up. Ideally I'm gonna have a music that changes depending on which biome of the level you're in.

zeina.summary: Zeina has plans to contribute her own hand-drawn art for the clouds in the craft level.
zeina.quote: Zeina wants to draw in clouds anyway, so I'm attaching them right now.

zeina.summary: Zeina is actively working on an animation, referred to as the '13' animation, though its context is not specified.
zeina.quote: Zeina is working on it right now. It's not finished.

key_stories.title: Taming the Spin Jump
key_stories.summary: Kaze identified that the spin jump was too powerful and was breaking his level design. He iteratively nerfed and redesigned the move, transforming it from a height-gaining exploit into a deliberate, slow aerial stall meant for recovering from mistakes.
key_stories.challenge: The spin jump mechanic was so powerful that it allowed players to bypass intended platforming challenges by easily climbing vertical surfaces, breaking the game's design.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified the issue while testing level geometry. He then adjusted the move's physics, reducing its initial velocity and horizontal control to change its function from a traversal tool to a recovery mechanic.
key_stories.outcome: The move was redesigned to be a slow, aerial stall focused on recovery. It no longer provides significant height, preserving the integrity of the level design while still offering players a safety net.
key_stories.key_quote: I want this to be a very slow thing, that you kind of like do not want to use, but that gives you a feeling of security when it's available to you.

key_stories.title: The Thimble Shy Guy's Identity Crisis
key_stories.summary: To create an enemy for the craft level, Kaze decided to make a Shy Guy out of a thimble. This led to a long, iterative design process on stream as he struggled to model and texture the object to look convincingly like a bumpy, metallic thimble within the N64's technical limitations.
key_stories.challenge: The craft-themed level needed a fitting enemy. The team decided on Shy Guys, but faced the creative challenge of designing one that looked like it was made from common craft materials.
key_stories.process: Kaze settled on a thimble as the base concept. He then went through a lengthy, public trial-and-error process on stream, modeling the shape, struggling to make it look metallic, and experimenting with multiple texture layers and blending modes on the N64 to simulate a bumpy, reflective surface.
key_stories.outcome: After a long process of modeling and texturing, Kaze created a 'thimble Shy Guy' with a custom bumpy, metallic-looking texture that he was satisfied with. This new enemy will be used in a mission to rescue a Peach doodle.
key_stories.key_quote: Look at that. Now he's a nice bumpy little fella. Alright, I think we've got our simple guy.

key_stories.title: Reinventing the Lighting Wheel
key_stories.summary: Kaze implemented a custom lighting effect to simulate reflectivity, referring to it as a normal map. His community debated the correct term, but Kaze, unconcerned with the exact name, demonstrated his practical, results-driven approach to programming by successfully creating the effect he envisioned.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze wanted a dynamic lighting effect to make surfaces like styrofoam look reflective, but had to implement it from scratch within the N64's hardware constraints.
key_stories.process: Kaze wrote code to calculate light reflection into the camera based on surface normal data. He called it a 'normal map,' which sparked a debate with his chat about the correct terminology (specular map, bump map, etc.). Despite the confusion, he focused on the practical result rather than the name.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a custom shader that simulates specular highlights based on camera and light angles, achieving his desired visual effect even if he was unsure of its proper industry name.
key_stories.key_quote: I don't know the name of it, but I know how to program it.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions specific tasks for each core team member: Biobak handling art assets, Badub composing music, and Zeina creating animations. The workflow appears collaborative but potentially siloed.
questions: Can you walk me through the typical lifecycle of an idea? For example, with the Thimble Shy Guy, at what point do you bring in Biobak for art or Badub for sound design?
You mentioned hoping for dynamic music from Badub. How do you communicate your vision for a level's soundtrack? Do you send gameplay footage, reference tracks, or written descriptions?
How do you and Zeina navigate creative disagreements when your professional work on the game intersects with your personal relationship as a married couple?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated a firm rule: "We're not adding anything that was invented after Nintendo 64 unless we invented it ourselves." This is a core creative pillar of the project.
questions: Why is this 'N64-era only' rule so important to the project's identity? What feeling are you trying to preserve or create with this limitation?
Has there ever been a character or mechanic from a newer game, like Galaxy or Odyssey, that you were really tempted to include? What was it, and what made you stick to your rule?
How does this constraint force you to be more creative when you need a new mechanic or enemy that doesn't have a direct N64-era equivalent?

open_questions.context: Kaze received community feedback that the craft level looked "blocky" and "boring." He defended the blocky style as an intentional choice to evoke the feeling of cardboard construction.
questions: You said the level 'has to look blocky for the effect to work.' Can you elaborate on your philosophy of using simple geometry to create a strong aesthetic identity?
How do you balance listening to community feedback with staying true to your own creative vision, especially when that vision is intentionally simplistic or unconventional?
Beyond just looking like cardboard, what story or feeling are you trying to tell with the craft level's design?

open_questions.topic: Passion for Detail and Unseen Work
open_questions.context: Kaze briefly showed a highly detailed aquarium in another level, commenting, "I put so much work into random shit like this." This hints at significant off-stream development and a passion for small details.
questions: You showed an aquarium with bubbles that chase each other. What's the story behind that? Why invest so much effort into a small, ambient detail?
What are some other 'random' details you've spent a lot of time on that players might not immediately notice? What drives you to perfect these small elements?
How much of the game's development happens off-stream? What are the biggest pieces of the game that your streaming audience hasn't seen yet?
